Once the cache comments are resolved I think we can take a look into merging this.

As NotFilter relies on complement operation of bitmap, 
this bug probably results in incorrect result at not operation.

I think that it seems to be from duplicated exclusion of complement range end at flip() of MutableRoaringBitmap and not() of MappeableContainer.

If a range (rangeStart, rangeEnd) is given to flip(), it consider rangeStart as inclusive begining of range and rangeEnd as exclusive end of range, which means it only checks range from rangeStart to rangeEnd - 1.
However, not() excludes the end of given range again, which means it only checks range from rangeStart to rangeEnd - 2.
So, last bit of the given roaring bitmap is excluded from complement operation.

I think it shoud be fixed at RoaringBitmap not Druid :)

@fjy made various changes to address all review comments, pls take another look. I have placed links for users to learn details about ingestion spec etc, this doc focuses on data updation only.

I understand that this is more efficient. I think ideally Druid should be able to separate having filters into work that can be performed on the brokers and work that needs to be done in the post process step. While a smart library like Plywood could auto split the having filters to leverage this use-case users using the native Druid API directly would benefit from this greatly.

I found that current version of RoaringBitmap already fixed the bug.
And github source of com.metamx.bytebuffer-collections is also updated to use new RoaringBitmap (version 0.5.13).
Unfortunately, however, updated com.metamx.bytebuffer-collections is not released yet.
So, current released version bytebuffer-collections.0.2.1 still depends on old version of RoaringBitmap (0.5.4) which has bug on handling complement.

I have no idea about who is responsible for bytebuffer-collection package.
So, @fjy, can you push the release of new version?
can you pls update relevant documentation with new metric?

Here are some performance numbers which I tested on my laptop.
The input are 1 million rows with 100 dimension with high and low cardinality, and 20 simple metrics.
I set rowFlushBoundary to 100000 because of the memory pressure, so there will be 10 persist and 1 big merge.

The old way(create V8, then convert to V9):
total persist time: 101.3s ( 10 persists)
total merge time: 89.2s 

The new way(create V9 directly):
total persist time: 65.641113s
total merge time: 53.852s

The performance gain is about: (101.3+89.2-65.6-53.8)/(101.3+89.2) = 37.3%
The memory pressure is also reduced since we did not have to load all data into heap when converting v8 to v9.
@KurtYoung These performance numbers are great. There's a few conflicts in the branch right now. Also, do you know why we can't comment in IndexMergerV9.java?

@fjy, i  think may be this is the reason: https://help.github.com/articles/what-are-the-limits-for-viewing-content-and-diffs-in-my-repository/
The limit is 1500 lines and current we have 1600+ lines. There are some static class like DimValueConverter and MMappedIndexRowIterable which are copied from IndexMerger, I can change these class to public static and use then from IndexMeger to reduce the diff line numbers.
Conflicts had been resolved, and we can make comments for IndexMergerV9 now.
